comments.commentBody:
David,

" global temperature products."

A great way of describing something which has been constructed - a product.

http://stevengoddard.wordpress.com/hansen-the-climate-chiropractor/

In answer to your question, no.  I used to live in Idaho.  People of the more conservative ilk from California often move to the Boise area.  And there are lots of guns throughout the state.  One day someone carried a gun into the library where I had recently started working and put it on the desk where he was using the computer.  He stared at me, and since I didn't know what to do, I did nothing.  The next day I asked the director if carrying guns into the library was allowed, and she said it was.  The only exception was that they were not allowed in the children's room.  She figured that no one would object to that.

Oh, I almost forgot the law that prevents any federal funds from being used on research into the societal effects of guns.

=======================

What law would that be? Another one of those progressive myths again. The CDC produced a report on gun violence at President Obama's request last summer. You never heard about it because the facts it relates don't support the gun control agenda.

http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=18319&page=

Here is a serious research question.  Would permitting guns on campuses in pro-gun states result in depopulating those states enough to reduce their representation in the House of Representatives?  Oh, I almost forgot the law that prevents any federal funds from being used on research into the societal effects of guns.  Maybe Idaho would like to contribute.
Your sureness is all in your head.

WVC, apparently there are many tracks, and you were on one of them. Searching on 'Snow Dome' [w/o 'Mt'], I discovered there are at least 3 covered ski runs, 2 in Germany and 1 in Staffordshire, England, for 3-season skiing. I'm just grateful that there's one Snow Dome that will remain unenclosed.

Thanks for directing me to Burns Lake, which I had a great time browsing. Looks as if you are indeed about 1/2 way between the two Princes, and hip-deep in lakes, marshes and NATIONAL Protected Areas. I almost had a chance to become bear-aware, but that Trail-Blazers video turned out to be private. I didn't see details, but it seems that woodmill explosion 2 years ago was a real tragedy.

All this is perfectly on-topic, of course, because of the ROCKIEs in the background. I took every chance to reminisce about the snow peaks we climbed, the CAVERS we were [briefly] and the bathing in 32 degree snow-melt [very briefly]. Thanks, am still smiling.

Tough puzzle- must have been a Canadian that constructed it!
He got me with gigantic- I never think of Texas [B.C. is larger] -I try not to think of Texas anyway!
The quad stack in the middle is a beauty.

@Leapy
If you google Burns Lake B.C. and scroll through the pictures it will give you an idea of what the area looks like.
Thanks for the info on the Snow Dome -I'd forgotten about that mountain. I was trying to think of a sports stadium around here that was called the Snow Dome. Funny the way the mind can get sidetracked!
I believe you mentioned that the other day.

Regards from WVC
9:03 PM

Yes, Anetliner, the TPP would indeed expedite the race to the bottom environmentally and further weaken worker rights everywhere. Maybe when developed nations get fed up enough things might change. Yesterday there was another day with a hazy soot hanging over Tokyo that often blows over from the numerous coal fired plants in China. The civilized and developed world is going to have to get together to force stricter air quality standards on their fast developing neighbors.

The ridiculous assertions often made that they deserve to catch up with the west for our past pollution sins can't be tolerated. Would any person who seriously thought that global warming were a threat to life as we know it even think such a thing, much less agree with the Chinese when they use that excuse?

Given that the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement address trade between nations comprising 40% of the global economy, transparency concerning its terms and effects is crucial. For Congress to grant 'fast track' authority to approve the Trans-Pacific Partnership without significant examination is an abrogation of democratic governance.

My own research about the act suggests that it would loosen regulation of multinationals by individual nations in favor of the lessened restrictions of the international TPP. While this would indeed enhance unrestricted international trade, it would also inhibit the ability of individual nations to levy environmental, health and labor requirements on companies operating within their jurisdiction. This has the potential to create a race to the bottom with respect to environmental. health and labor standards. This is great for multinational companies, but not so great for the rest of us.
Why should older workers make more than younger workers if they are doing the same minimum wage job?

We should raise the minimum wage for a number of reasons: (1) a large body of research has found that there is no negative effect on employment; (2) U.S. businesses have high profit margins; (3) for those businesses that would need to raise prices, a very modest increase would cover the extra cost of wages; and (4) taxpayers should not subsidize companies like Wal-Mart and McDonald’s by providing their employees with food stamps and other assistance because they do not pay a living wage.

Australia has an unemployment rate of only 6% even though their minimum wage is double the rate of the US: roughly $15.00-US for adult workers (younger workers are paid on a sliding scale). So the argument that jobs would be lost if we raise the minimum wage is bogus.

A higher minimum wage has a positive effect on middle class income and net worth. In 2011, the median wage was $57,400 in Australia (it’s $40,000 in the U.S.). Australians rank no. 1 in the world on median wealth: $219,505.

How is it that Australia can afford to pay a living wage and provide good benefits to their workers, including part-time and temp workers?

Business Profits as a Percentage of National Income:
U.S.: 20.4%
Australia: 12.7%

When workers make starvation wages, local economies suffer. An adult who works 40 hours a week deserves to earn a living wage. We should raise the wage to $15 for adult workers (younger workers should be paid on a sliding scale), in three incremental increases over a two-year period.

In 1994 Russia, the US and the UK signed an agreement that in exchange for giving up its nuclear arsenal, the three signatories would respect Ukraine's borders. So are we saying no w that the US and UK don't care about agreements they signed 20 years ago? you are wiling to abandon Ukraine to the Russians? Where next?

Russia created the balance of languages in eastern Ukraine wham Stalin murdered between 7 and 10 million Ukrainians by starvation in 1932/33 and repopulated the are with Russians. So now some people want to rewards Stalin's actions?

AS for proportion of population, there are more Chines by proportion than Russians in Russia's far east then there are Russian to Ukrainians in Crimea. Does this mean we should follow Russia's logic and tell Russia they must fed portions of eastern Siberia to China? Fairs fair. When China comes to take what is rightfully theirs by Russian logic, Russia better not come looking for help anywhere else.

Given the well-known incompetence of Ukraine's kleptocracy, Putin will succeed in orchestrating the independence of Crimea. Crimea will most likely be formally independent, but realistically be an appendage of Russia.

The real question is how badly the new regime in Kyiv will handle Crimean separatism. If the Western part of the country tries to attack the Eastern half, we can expect the entire Eastern region to secede along with Crimea.

Eastern Ukraine was just as sick of Yanukovich as the rest of the country and was quietly glad to have him gone. Unfortunately, the spineless politicians in Kyiv alienated the East by making Ukrainian the sole official language (no doubt in an attempt to appease the armed revolutionaries that put them in power). Some commentators on other NYTimes articles have suggested that the Ukrainians in the East should simply give up on their native language. This merely demonstrates their bizarre lack of knowledge about their own country: how is Ukrainian the native language in cities like Odessa, which used Russian since their founding?

Ukraine's thieving politicians, being idiots and lacking in character, are easy to predict. Even before parliament passed the language law, Russian television was talking about the language getting banned if the nationalist faction came to power. Ukraine should have new parliamentary elections immediately, before their current crop of venal idiots tears the country apart, feeding Putin the bleeding pieces.

It's all true, but Putin's situation is a bit different in case of Ukraine.

1994 Budapest memorandum

The United States of America, the Russian Federation, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, reaffirm their commitment to Ukraine, in accordance with the principles of the CSCE Final Act, to respect the Independence and Sovereignty and the existing borders of Ukraine.

The United States of America, the Russian Federation, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, reaffirm their obligation to refrain from the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of Ukraine, and that none of their weapons will ever be used against Ukraine except in self-defense or otherwise in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations.

The United States of America, the Russian Federation, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, reaffirm their commitment to Ukraine, in accordance with the principles of the CSCE Final Act, to refrain from economic coercion designed to subordinate to their own interest the exercise by Ukraine of the rights inherent in its sovereignty and thus to secure advantages of any kind.

The Crimea will be more valuable to Russia’s foreign policy as an independent or a quasi-independent country rather than the part of Russia. This will appease Russia’s internal demands to do something about protecting Russians in the Ukraine. On the other hand it will remain a valuable leverage for pressuring Ukraine and a possible “trading card” for the West. And most importantly it will reasonably protect the Russian population of Crimea from the fate of the Russian minority in the Baltics (denied citizenship and language restrictions). After all it’s only fair that if people in Kiev could choose their government the population of Crimea should also be allowed to do so by referendum.

So despite being the West’s "bad boy" Putin will disappoint NYT readers this time – no invasion will follow.

It's interesting how PK complained about how the TW deal stifled innovation, but is now passively taking an ambivalent stance of innovation in the TPP. Would not access to larger protection in global markets strengthen innovation?
Also, I don't see how it even benefits Big Pharma, would that not hasten the speed up of generic drug generation and eat at market share. Another Friday column with a lot left unanswered.

Of course the video will be reviewed. Natural language processing is already good enough to capture the audio and "understand" what is being said.

As computing power increases and machine learning gets better, the computers will be able to handle the video itself, and review, classify, and categorize the content. The government will have its own private You-Tube, fully indexed and cross referenced.

In fact, the video is just one source of information that the government is using to build profiles about you, me, and groups here and everywhere. Think about it: somewhere, at some time, the computers or analysts must, by definition of this entire process, classify the subject as friend or foe; over time, the classifications may become finer grained and nuanced. Therefore, it is being used.

As the laws and sensibilities evolve, other agencies will want a cut of the treasure. So, what started off as "terrorism" prevention, will be conflated to encircle "tax evasion", "pedophilia", "domestic abuse", "drunk driving" and so on.

Then the ethical questions will be raised: if the profiles can predict outcomes in real time, shouldn't they be used not just for "terrorism" prevention but also for general law enforcement? There ends "due process".

Finally, your assertion, "Not taking it adds to the risk that we will be attacked", is not proven. Nor is it clear that the ends ("terrorism prevention") justify the means ("mass surveillance by secret powers").

To call the Dirty War a foreign product is to completely underestimate the degree to which it was a product of the Argentine military and elites anti-Semitic, fascist ideology. It may have gotten some foreign support at times but the Argentines were quite capable of coming up with the Dirty War on their own, as well as the period of violence from both left and right that came before it.
Mr. Thomason: Are you Argentinian?

Jmbelan°South Bend
You're literally correct, but just as alcoholics are capable of getting and staying drunk, sometimes that disposition is motivated and facilitated by parties who know better and have a moral and ethical responsibility to act otherwise. The U.S. had the authority and responsibility to stop Argentina's military. We didn't.

Thousands of Argentinian mothers did. As a nation of, by, and for the people we still don't do enough there.

transcripts
October 6, 1976: Admiral Guzzetti is told by Charles Robinson, "...it is possible to understand the requirement to be tough; the problem is that the U.S. is an idealistic and moral country and its citizens have great difficulty in comprehending the kinds of problems faced by Argentina today".

October 7, 1976
Mr Kissinger: "Look, our basic attitude is that we would like you to succeed; I have an old-fashioned view that friends ought to be supported. What is not understood in the United States is that you have a civil war. We read about human rights problems, but not the context.

"The quicker you succeed the better ... The human rights problem is a growing one ... We want a stable situation. We won't cause you unnecessary difficulties. If you can finish before Congress gets back, the better. Whatever freedoms you could restore would help.

"There is a tendency to apply our moral standards abroad and Argentina must understand the reaction of Congress with regard to loans and military assistance. ...."
.

Argentina has experienced a fair amount of foreign meddling, all bad. The Dirty War was such a foreign import. There has been more.

Peronism is in part a nationalist reaction to that. It is other things, things that nationalists proclaim to be Argentina, but a large part of that is to be nationalist in the first place.

Peronism arose during the Great Depression, and it was much better than what arose in some other places. It was not the best, but it was not the worst either. FDR feared some would try to take the US down such a path too, and the New Deal was in part to ward off other things. Peronism in the same way warded off worse.

FDR and the men he recruited to help him had far better background and ability to run a nation than an Argentine Colonel and his regimental buddies. That is the source of much of Argentina's problems. Still, Peron and friends did a lot better than Gen Franco, a lot better than a newspaper editor leading a march in Italy, and worlds better than a rabble rousing corporal in Germany did at the same time.

Irony, Argentina now needs to move past that, while the US needs to go back to FDR's better version.

Are you really that naive?  Of course they use the camera in your computer - as well as your microphone.  All can be remotely turned on by the NSA etc.  Same in your phone, your tablet, your Xbox, etc etc etc.
Of course it is.

Obviously you didn't read the entire story or you didn't read it correctly!! That's already being done not only by the NSA and GCHQ but hackers around the world. The spy agencies of the world aren't the only ones hacking peoples webcams.

1984 is here. One wonders if it's possible to spy on someone using the camera built into the computer.  It's just a matter of time and computer power before all Skype contacts will be recorded and stored.  NSA assures us it's only storing metadata on phone calls, but with the technology comes the great temptation to use it in law enforcement.

Do you really think they're not going to delete their tracks on your system?? The NSA, GCHQ, and other spy agencies have software to do what they just did as reported in this story and they have the software to erase any and all details from your system of them having been there. Unless your a very savvy sysadmin and know your way around a Windows or Unix system you'll be digging all day/night looking for their digital fingerprints on your hard drive. You'd need something like FTK or EnCase to dig deep into your hard drive for this information and EnCase alone is somewhere around $5,000.00!! Do you have that kind of money laying around not to mention learning and knowing how to use it correctly.

br: let's follow through with this train of thought: if financial crimes have been committed and fraud perpetrated upon the people, then the records of that crime should be as easily found and readily available to the authorities as is a porno-search by some NSA employee. But notice that in the financial arena, the crimes become "very convoluted" and "difficult to explain" and "very hard to deduce" and the evidence "disappears" or the trail of the money is "hypothicated into oblivion" so that the criminals are either not found at all (Jamie Dimon, Jon Corzine, Lloyd Blankfein, Too-Big-To-Fail & Jail Banks, etc), or the low lying fruit operatives plucked easily, arrested and tossed into the judicial rubbish bin - aka prison (Madoff etc).

So, yes - it's pure rot and a fraud upon the people of this country, and is nothing more than the attempts by the government to control, frighten and subject to extreme prejudice, the governed.

This one shouldn't be overly difficult. Computers leave tracks, so it should not be overly difficult to determine which people, precisely, accessed these images. Charge them with crimes, then throw them in jail upon conviction, five years minimum. If the government won't do this, then anything the government says about electronic snooping is pure rot.

And how many terrorists plots have been stopped from looking at our naked pics and video game faces?

Looking for needles in haystacks is a waste of time and money and worse, a horrible invasion of privacy with little or nothing to show for it. More people die from the flu and we don't feel the need to forcibly innoculate and quarantine people. Then why does all logic and common sense go out the window when it comes to technology?

Steve R:
Explain why the 2nd ammendment is not as worthy as the 4th ammendment? The 1st has been nullified, since journalists are being targeted and victimized for not revealing their sources, and protestors are arrested for exercising freedom of assembly. The 3rd has been nullified now that police and military can seize and occupy your home - as happened during Katrina, or in the case of drug raids gone horribly wrong. The 5th has been nullified by the use of drones to assassinate Americans abroad without due process or a trial by their peers.
One can either support ALL of the constitutional ammendments, or none of them. It's not a pick and choose situation. Either there is the Rule of Law, or there isn't. Your choice.

America was born due to a mistrust of government a using its power. We go  too far in this concern at times (read guns) but I am amazed there is not more outrage over our government spying on citizens without any basis except that terrorists may try to attack. A very flimsy rationale.

The TPP might be an opportunity to extract some trade concessions from our partners in ameliorating the social costs of manufacturing waste, which regulation in the US adds to our cost of production.  Those corporations that outsource  production to Asian and other countries also outsource those manufacturing wastes and their attendant costs.  A trade agreement requiring those costs to at least be attached to other costs of manufacture would certainly raise the cost of outsourced labor, and possibly return some jobs to the US, particularly with some clever informational advertising by US labor associations.

Alan, the problem with this is that it is a variation of, "If you've got nothing to hide, you've got nothing to fear."

That line of thinking has not been acceptable in this country for many reasons. Not the least of which is that it is demonstrably untrue.

It's better than living in a police state being ordered by the likes of you to "keep our mouths shut", as you do. We have the right of free speech, and the right not to be searched or to have our effects (including online) seized without warrants that state the probable cause for searching us, individually.

And the risk of losing that because of "terrorism", in a nation that's been through world wars and great depressions without abandoning our Constitution--with forbears who were willing to DIE for our freedoms--is certainly worth taking. How horrible that so many are cowardly enough to give away their rights when the fear-mongers scowl and threaten. But don't you think we all will. Because we won't.

Montaigne seems to embody somewhat of an Asian outlook, insofar as he emphasizes calm understanding and the flow of nature. Johnson, by contrast, embodies a Western perspective steeped in effort and self-improvement.

Based on life experience, I submit that both approaches are valuable. Calm self-acceptance is an excellent stance for accepting the world and achieving life balance, but the Western emphasis on concrete accomplishment helps to propel us forward. I vote for individual and organizational balance between these two poles.
Its not the poop, its the, ahem, unmentionable acts that might incriminate you.  Or maybe pooping is one of those acts.  Beats me.

You speak the truth - and as guilt is in the eye of the beholder, subjective as well as objective, if a crime is needed to be found to justify some course of action, a crime and a criminal will be found. Pursuing "thought crimes" are the next step, and this collection of data puts all of us at risk. Any comment that is counter to the government and its policies can now be taken as a threat that needs to be "addressed." How much longer will it be until the use of drone strikes within the US are justified as necessary and permissable? The Supreme Court ruled just yesterday that warrantless searches of peoples homes and seizures of their property are now allowed - completely negating the 4th Ammendment. Environmentalists are considered "terrorists by the authorities. Anti-nuke activists are considered "domestic terrorists." Animal rights activists are considered "terrorists."

"The assault on our civil liberties will continue, until moral improves."
No one ever seizes power with the intention of relinquishing it.   You are not being protected, you are a suspect until someone decides you are guilty.

Why bother, unless you have something to hide? You are tracked by your phone, by your IP address, the Garmin in your car, by the street cameras, by the police scanners that record everyone's license plates/movements, etc etc etc...

I hate the notion that anyone can spy on me, but I know there's little I can do about it, unless I am obsessive about it. And even then, it's futile if I'm a target worth spying on - NSA will bounce lasers off my walls/windows and record my conversations, will place surreptitious hardware in my devices and a slew of other surveillance I'm not even aware of.

Paul, thank you for your sane and reasonable willingness to be recorded in your affairs, and for your pointing out that if one has nothing to hide, one is best advised to accept the status quo and it coming updates without argument, complaint, or efforts to resist.

Sincerely,
The NSA
Not only did I remove my Webcam/Microphone, but I just deleted the Skype program. Maybe minimalist is better?

Well, turning off your camera/microphone etc, is pointless.  The NSA can remotely operate/turn on any device.  The only effective solution is to physically remove cameras/microphones.  And even then, that's not foolproof, as NSA and others can insert special hardware into your devices (they regularly intercept products bought thru the mail from places like Amazon, and insert the hardware without the target's knowledge)

Paul: I'm talking about prudent precautions, not a lifestyle change. Nobody can remotely plug in a camera, flip an analog switch or remove electrical tape from a laptop camera and microphone. After that, I'd say the problem becomes too large. It's just like robbery-proofing your house. If your house takes more than thirty seconds to get into, they say, there are a lot of other houses on the block.

If hackers or the CIA or whatever group has targets a person specifically, that's a completely different story. My philosophy is that you do as much as you reasonably can to protect yourself opportunists and idiots, and then it's up to fate. There are lots of stories about people who had life-long fear of something, did everything to avoid that kind of death, and were hit by a falling piano or something. You can't let fear rule your life. (But it does make me look a little more sideways at my smart phone.)

And Paul, it's not just the NSA. It's almost anybody with the right level of hacker abilities. With training and intention/desire, anyone could hack into your home. I'm sure that's why NSA is doing this - they know what's possible, and right or wrong (sadly I think they don't know) they want to get a jump on it.

I've always thought the only thing that kept people from snooping on us would be the sheer amount of people and data to be sifted through. If you can share it, it can also be taken. I used to say to friends, if you don't cover your web cam ports and disconnect cameras, turn off your microphone, leave your sensitive stuff out there, you deserve what you get. I shut up after awhile because they thought I was being a bit obsessive.

Well I feel vindicated, but not in a happy way. A new twist on an old saying: Just because everyone thinks you are paranoid, doesn't mean there's nobody out to get you.
